Portal 2 is just like Portal 1.

BUT EVEN BETTER.

[h1]Portal 2 Review [/h1]

so here is my review.
I will be dividing the review into 4 sections: Graphics, Gameplay, Mods, Story.

[b]Graphics:[/b]
As a game that's nearly 11 year old it's surprising to say that the graphics still held up to date and is maybe comparable to modern titles, but it's a source so it's not really surprising to say since most if not all of valve titles using the source engine still looks good even today (except Half-Life Source, we don't talk about that). Even at the lowest settings, I still find the graphics to be decent. 

10/10

[b]Gameplay:[/b]
The gameplay is practically the same as it's predecessor, Portal 1, although Portal 2 does introduce new mechanics like the gels and the tractor beam. The game consists of chapters, with each chapter having a different themed test chamber, and some being outside of the test chambers, or backstage aperture. The levels outside of the test chambers are my favorite, the idea of a super large science corporation that has a comically large science facility is amazing, so being able to explore the facility is really great, it really tells you about Aperture science and it's history. 

The Portal franchise is known for it's gameplay that's for everybody, and it's true. No matter if you're an experienced gamer or just someone trying out games for the first time, or even a 70 year old grandpa, this game is for everybody. The gameplay is not necessarily challenging but of  course it's not that easy either, it's pretty balanced between both really. 

It also has a co-op mode, I don't know if it's still alive, I recommend either playing with your friend or joining into some portal community groups. The co-op mode is really great, it even has a story, I recommend you playing it after finishing the main campaign.

10/10

[b]Mods:[/b]
This game has some masterpieces of a mod. Portal Stories: Mel, a mod that has a brilliant story and also a brilliant soundtrack you definitely should check out. Another one is Portal: Reloaded which introduces a new mechanic, a third Portal, although I've never personally played so I don't really know how it plays but it's one of the most recent big mods I think. Also the mods it's not limited to the ones listed at Portal 2 game page, there's some great mods outside of steam as well, with one being in the works like Aperture 77. There's probably hundreds of great mods out there that I haven't tried so explore for yourself.

it also has a built in test chamber editor, it's good enough for puzzle making but visually not flexible enough, you're limited to the clean test chamber style only, it's still pretty limited. I'm pretty sure there's a mod out there that makes the test chamber editor has more components and could also change the test chamber style, but I forgot what the name is.

(I don't really know how to rate this part)

[b]Story:[/b]

[i]It's great, find it out yourself.[/i]

10/10

Terminei o modo co-op. Jogo muito bom para quebrar a cabe√ßa com gr√°ficos nada al√©m do esperado. Comprei por na promo√ß√£o, mas com certeza vale 20 reais.

Last weekend I played Portal and Portal 2 for the first time, 10 years late. My feelings on Portal 2 are very similar to Portal. It's a game that was important in the industry, so it's worth playing for historic reasons, but it's not really all that compelling when put up against contemporary walking sims and narrative adventures.

The story is basically the same as the original Portal, except it takes 10 hours to get through instead of 4, which makes it a bit tedious. On the other hand, the mechanics have been massively improved. No longer will you open a portal under a cube to warp it away, only to see it jankily dangle there doing nothing.

The game feels really smooth and forgiving, right up until (you guessed it) the boss fight, and similar cinematic set-pieces. In those scenes you're just expected to die repeatedly until you memorize the right sequence of events, and that sucks. The other thing that sucks is the number of jumping puzzles. One in particular is infuriatingly difficult to get. But - also - there are some genuinely funny sections to balance the frustration. Not the narration - that gets old after the second room - but I won't soon forget running around that room where you need to catch a bouncy block for the first time. Or the block that walks off the button on its own. Portal 2 has some grade A physical comedy, which is rare in single player games.

So, thumbs up for the occasional laugh-out-loud sections. Thumbs in the middle for story. Thumbs down for boss fights and jumping puzzles. Overall still worth playing, if it's on sale.
